div1.p: Immunity to Yellow Fever

p.del: (From a Lecture for the Laboratory Class, U. S. Public Health Service.)

div1.p:
(Here is another debatable question.) Is the immunity produced
by an attack of yellow fever permanent or temporary? Naturally a
disease caused by micro-organisms and which recovers spontaneously
must produce immunity local or general, temporal or permanent, else
one would not recover. That it is permanent has been, and is now,
the opinion of American epidemiologists and of the older genera-
tion of the French and English writers, who added so much to our
knowledge of this disease by their observations in the West Indies
and in Africa.

There was, however, a very common belief among the laity of
localities in which yellow fever was endemic that leaving such fo-
cus of endemicity for a sufficient time would restore the suscep-
tibility to the disease. This belief is alluded to by many writers.
It was, I think, universally regarded as erroneous by those not
living in endemic areas, but given more consideration, althoughand
-2-
not, I think, generallysometimes - I think not generally - affirmed by writers who lived in such en-
demic areas. It is fair to say that epidemiological investigations
of disease are far more apt to lead to correct conclusions when
made in countries in which the disease is not endemic. The reason
for this is too obvious to require explanation.

On the other hand the Commission of the Pasteur Institute
(Marchoux, Simond and Salembeni) state categorically that the im-
munity produced by an attack of yellow fever gives temporary immu-
nity only and that the infection is kept up in endemic centers by
recurrent attacks among the indigenes. This view is accepted by
Seidelin and Rubbert Boyce and some other recent British writers.

I have seen no evidence advanced, except by Seidelin, in
support of this view. I am inclined to think that the Pasteur Com-
mission may have been influenced by the opinion which I have stated
is common in localities of yellow fever endimicity. I will not say
that no evidence--except as stated--has been advanced for this view--
but I certainly have seen none.

I have said that I have seen no evidence for this last view.
Looking insto that for the first, that one attack produced permanent
-3-
immunity--which I hold--I am surprised to see that we have almost
as little, which would be accepted by those holding the contrary,
for our own. We have simply accepted previous opinion and not find-
ing it contradicted by obvious facts have not examined the matter
critically. We assume that one attack gives permanent protection.
Obviously then, we would not be apt to consider an attack of illness
occurring in one who had previously had yellow fever as yellow fever
unless it were (1) well marked: or (2) clearly gave rise to yellow
fever in others. The first might not be the case with light, cer-
tainly not with ephemoral, attacks--the kind which would naturally
occur as secondary attacks: The second we will consider presently.

Even if a secondary attack were clearly yellow fever one with
our belief would, in the absence of good evidence to the contrary,
question the diagnosis of the previously reported attack. This it
is natural to do because we know how many cases of other diseases are
diagnosticated as yellow fever during an epidemic. I did this in
the case of Assistant Surgeon Groenveldtan officer of this service, who died of yellow fever
under my care at Chandeleur in 1890. He was reported to have had yellow
fever in /78. For the acceptance of a secondary attack it would
-4-
require then that a well marked case of yellow fever occur twice in
the same person. Now even under the doctrine of temporary immunity
this would be rare, as those who hold it also hold that there would
be a greatly lowered susceptibility and that if the attacks were not
very far apart that the second one would be mild, or very mild which is new trouble and that is remarkable. You
can see then that we have not been in a proper state of mind to ex-
amine this part of the question critically, and indeed I, at least,
have not done so. Even allowing for this the number of second at-
tacks reported in places in which yellow fever occurs only in epi-
demics--the only places in which we would expect them--are exceed-
ingly rare. They are reported, however, and the recognition of
such cases is proof that our eyes are not so blinded by our belief
that we cannot recognise second attacks of yellow fever if they be
plain enough. I have seen three cases of yellow fever in people who
x were supposedsaid to have had a previous attack. In two of them the
evidence for the first attack seemed to me to be slight; the third
I could not inquire into P When I come to individual cases--men who
had yellow fever at one epidemic and were exposed to it a second
time after a considerable interval, and I have seen many such--the
-5-
most I can say is that I have not known a second attack to be re-
ported. Drs. P(urnell) and Waldauer had yellow fever in Memphis in
/79 and /78 respectively and were not exposed again until /97 at Edwards house after
intervals of 18 and 19 years. Purnell was not reported to have yel-
low fever at Edwards, but he was sick there with the diagnosis of
malarial fever which was also prevalent, and to which he was subject.
Waldauer was not sick at all. Major GorgasGorgas had yellow fever in Brownsville, Texas /82. No expos-
ure until /98 at Siboney, Cuba, 16 years later. He was sick at Si-
boney, diagnosis malarial fever, which was extremely prevalent. He
did have malaria; plasmodia demonstrated and recurrent attacks for a-
bout a year, but that by no means excludes the possibility of yellow
fever. Dr. Pierce of this Service, yellow fever at Chatanooga, Tenn.
1878, next exposure Panama 1903--26 years interval. He was, after
nearly a year's residence in good health in Panama City, sick at Ancon
Hospital in Oct./04 with what I myself thought was going to develope
into a severe attack of yellow fever until a typical eruption appear-
ed and dengue was diagnosticated. I feel sure that the last case
was dengue--although it was before we knew the diagnostic value of
-6-
the blood picture, for it was a severe case and such are well mark-
ed. The exception was well marked, & others you, Yet you see that one believing that secondary cases are common
might find fault with the diagnosis of all of them. I could add of
my own knowledge I think from 25 to 50 cases to the above, but they
would be more or less similar. Some did not get sick on the second
or subsequent exposures, yet that is not convincing. Some people--
who have never had yellow fever--go through an epidemic unscathed.
Also light attacks might well escaped any notice.

The difficulty is that we recognize no sign pathognomonic for
all cases of yellow fever, the mild and ephemeral as well as the
severe. It is true that Seidelin claims to have such a sign in his
Paraplasma flavigenum and also to have demonstrated it in a secon-
dary (ephemoral) case of yellow fever in himself and in others--some
of whom shewed no symptoms of illness--i. e. were “carriers.” With-
out in any way pronouncing on the validity of his claims, yet un-
til his primary contention is confirmed we cannot accept the exist-
ence of his bodies as pathognomic of yellow fever and hence proving
a second attack.

The second test, that yellow fever was communicated to others
-7-
from cases of sickness of undeterminate nature of men who had pre-
viously had yellow fever is again hard for us to apply.

When you consider how freely men “protected by a previous at-
tack of yellow fever” have been allowed to move from places viru-
lently infected with that disease into susceptible communities in
the U. S. and how many hundreds of times this has occurred during epedemics you would
think we should have satisfactory data on this subject, positive or
negative. If not immune to yellow fever some of these men should
have contracted it and developed it, and even if not diagnosticated,
it should have infected mosquitoes and spread to others in whom the
diagnosis would be easy. An epidemic cannot be hidden.

I know of no evidence that this has occurred, yet the evidence
to the contrary has not been scrutinized critically. Since we did
not believe that secondary cases of yellow fever occurred --or oc-
curred very rarely--if an outbreak occurred we would be little apt to impute conveyance of
yellow fever from any sickness as occurreding among people who were
“protected by a previous attack of yellow fever”--if an outbreak of
yellow fever occurred. Almost any other hypothesis would be accept-
ed to explain it. Indeed, in times of epidemics there are so many
ways in which infection can be introduced that an outbreak without
-8-
our being able to explain its introduction is not to be wondered at.

To use this test then, we must depend on the scrutiny of the
exposures of susceptible communities to cases of sickness of such
“protected” men, who had themselves been exposed to yellow fever,
under such conditions, that other sources of exposure of the com-
munity are exluded. Opportunity for this would rarely occur during
an epidemic. Obviously in such a scrutiny one positive observation
--i. e. the developement of yellow fever in the susceptible commu-
nity if we know that there is not other source of infection, would
be conclusive. On the other hand, it would require many negative
observations, many failures of of susceptible communities thus to
receive infection, to be at all convincing. This would be negative
testimony and is convincing only in proportion to its mass. I know of no positive observations on this subject. It
seems useless to relate the 25 or 30--maybe 50--negative observa-
tions I could give you. They are not enough to be convincing.

Possibly, however, we have in the passenger traffic of the Plant
S. S. Line data of sufficient mass to be worth considering. From 1889 to 1897 inclusive--9 years--there was no bar to the
transit on these vessels from Havana to Key West and Tampa of pas-
-9-
sengers “protected against yellow fever by previous attack or ten
years residence in an endemic focus” and a great many of them came:
Cubans on their 10 years residence and Americans on certificate of
previous attack. How many I canfor an attempt to only approximately estimate. There
were cigar factories in Key West: Tampa and Jacksonville, all manned
by Cuban employees. There was generally one vessel per week, but
Havana was about 6 hours from Key West & 24 from Tampa
part of the time two vessels. From my own observations I would es-
timate the weekly passenger list at from 20 to 50. During the hot
season, from April 15th. to Nov. 1st.--28 weeks--this would give at
the lowest estimate 700560 such passengers per annum--63005040 during the
9 years. Now remember that this very considerable number of people,
and I have given you minimal numbers, came from a city where yellow
fever was endemic: that they came in hot weather: to towns where
Stegomyia were abundant and where people susceptible to yellow fever
were also abundant. If then, any considerable proportion of them
had been infective to Stegomyia I cannot but think that there would
have been at least one outbreak of yellow fever in Florida during
these nine years. There was none.

That others those susceptible to yellow fever were liable to contract
that disease from exposure in Havana at this time was evidenced by
the history of vessels from that part whose personnel had not had
yellow fever. They frequently brought cases of yellow fever to our
quarantine station. Why In 1895 at the Dry Tortugas I had 13 cases
of yellow fever on Havana vessels out of a crew list of less than
450 men. Indeed the crew list of men exposed to infection at Havana
was not over half of 450, as the steamers lay in a safe part of the
harbor--Trisconia--and allowed only a very few men ashore and were
practically free from fever. It occurred (with one exception) only
-10-
on vessels which had laid on the Havana side of the harbor. Un-
questionably then those susceptible to yellow fever could contract
it in Havana during this time.
Compare these observations:

450 people who had not had yellow fever, from Havana,
gave 13 cases of yellow fever, every one of which should have been infective
to Stegomyia.

Over 65000 people from the same place, during a period covering the same time,
give no evidence of infecting Stegomyia: certainly
give rise to no outbreak in the susceptible communi-
ties into rhic into which they move.

You may not consider this proof. There may not be enough of
it to satisfy you; but the mass of this evidence, negative as it is,
is sufficient, until the contrary is proven, to confirm me in the
belief that one attack of yellow fever confers permanent immunity
against becoming again infective to Stegomyia mosquitoes and that
we are justified in basing sanitary measures thereon. This obser-
vation is also inconsistent with the existence of “carriers” as a common phenomenon capa-
ble of infecting Stegomyia with yellow fever. against which indeed
a strongest argument is stronger can be made. stronger.

I said “Until the contrary is proven”, because if it is shown
that the organism causative of yellow fever occurs in men who have
had previous attacks of this disease and is conveyable from them
by Stegomyia mosquitoes to other men, producing yellow fever in them
I will count the contrary proven. I well know how much more deter-
minative are the results of experimental than epidemiological ob-
servations. Yet in this disease it was, I believe, the latter that
gave the key to the problem, which determined the direction of the
experimental investigation which demonstrated the method of convey-
ance.

There are other epidemiological observations which are at least
consistent with the doctrine of permanent immunity, such as the spontane-
ous disappearance of yellow fever from small and moderate sized
towns in the tropics which receive few susceptible immigrants. I
do not mean that this always occurs, but it is by no means rare in
America and will be discussed later. The great decrease of infec-
tion in Havana in 1899, due to falling off of immigration in the
previous years, is also consistent with it. This was shown in the
small number of cases of yellow fever in the spring and summer of
that year, as compared with normal yearsas compared with normal years although the town was full of Americans who went every-
